Works really well - I have it set up to control my A/V amp, Sky box, TV, Sonos, Blu-Ray player all with things like "Watch music TV" so it switches everything on and turns the Sky box to my favourite music channel, or "Listen to Sam's Faves" so my wife can press that and it switched the amp to the Sonos, switching the TV and Sky box off if they were on, and selecting the playlist I set up of my wife's favourite music.

My only criticisms are the touch-screen can't be configured so the menu items are bigger so if you have sausage-fingers you'd have to be more careful and the touch response is ok, but not that of an Apple touch screen.

When using it to search for something on Sky and you swipe the display to the side to get the keypad/keyboard up, like a phone you have to press certain keys 2 or 3 times to get the letter you want and it doesn't always register each press so you end up with gobbledegook in the search field on Sky and have to keep backspacing.

It's easy to set up the first time, but the real charm is when you have to replace it, as I just have after my original gave up after 4 years of good service.
Plugged the replacement in, fired up the myharmony software and synchronised, 2 minutes and it was ready to go, and working exactly the same as the one it replaced.
For the money, you absolutely cannot go wrong with this remote.

Having recently obtained an Amazon Echo I wanted to explore the options for voice controlling my AV setup - I purchased a refurbished Harmony Hub to carry out my experiment.

The end result greatly exceeds my expectations, using the Harmony Hub with the Echo now allows me turn on the TV, change channels, pause/play etc as well as change inputs into the AV amp and controlling the input device all by voice control The Harmony Home Hub is a great bit of kit

From what I had read and watched, I expected the set up to be difficult - however, while it does take time to input the information for all of the devices, I was pleasantly surprised how easy it was to follow the iOS Harmony app.
Furthermore, linking the setup to the Alexa App was also relatively straight forward.

The end result greatly exceeds my expectations, using the Harmony Hub with the Echo now allows me turn on the TV, change channels, pause/play etc as well as change inputs into the AV amp and controlling the input device all by voice control The Harmony Home Hub is a great bit of kit
The Hub arrived in its original box with all parts and instructions included.

It's weird that Logitech really don't have any real competitors yet though, I'd have happily explored some alternatives but there's really nothing that can compare with Logitech's "activities" system where the individual sequences automatically know what they need to power on, power off, or whether they are just changing inputs and other such intricacies.
Personally I think the tipping point is if you're running a discreet audio system, because that's one remote that requires constant input in addition to whichever remote you're actually using.

I quickly realised this is one of those things that myself and the family have started taking for granted, and just one night coping with the more standard alternatives was enough for me to order a replacement immediately.

From new the remote is functionally well thought through and the software, although rather prescriptive, allows you to create a more customised set up than more basic learning remotes.
Cheap TV remotes, given away with a TV, generally do not suffer with button failures on this scale, especially after less than two years use.
However having owned a Harmony 350 for less than two years I am now about to throw it away as five buttons have stopped working.
I even reprogrammed two unused buttons to control volume and one of those buttons failed within a few weeks.
One also has to wonder if the more costly Harmony 650 also uses the same buttons.

Having seen several reviews with this same fault I must come to the conclusion the Harmony 350 is a floored design.

Firstly even without Alexa and the Echo it gives me the option to add wireless plugs and lights to my network and control with my harmony remote and my phone, this is decent for quickly turning off lights and stuff around the house.
Secondly, the hub itself makes the controller work so much better than it did before.
The one downside of the touch controller prior to the hub was that you had to point it at the tv/ devices all the way through until the sequance was finished.
This sometimes caused issues if you moved the controller or, if you have a monther-in-law like mine who can't work this out.
With the hub, the signals are sent once from the controller and then from the hub to your devices.

Once you have devices set up, the app guides you through creating "activities", which are basically a set of instructions to a group of devices.
Firstly it's important to know that only one "activity" can run at a time via the Harmony Hub.
For example the "Watch TV" activity tells the TV to switch on and tune to HDMI1, the Sky Box to switch on and tune to Sky One, and the sound bar to switch on.
Once you start an activity with Alexa there are also extension commands you can use like "Volume up".
Yet "Turn on the TV" worked to run the activity called "Watch TV" on the Harmony hub!

One suggestion for your home automation project would be if at all possible to set up all the apps on a separate email address and password to your main one, and to connect all devices to a "guest" network on your router.

I think this should be a good solution to simplify a home cinema setup (where you press a couple of buttons then sit back for 90 minutes), or for someone in your household who struggles a bit with switching inputs and remotes with too many buttons.

It's just sluggish enough that you really have the feeling it's a full blown computer with layers of operating system and middleware, compared to a simple microcontroller in your average cheap remote, that reacts instantly.
But it's not quite the thing for actively browsing through a Youtube app on your set top box of choice - you'll end up reverting to the real remote.
In short, it works pretty well but I quickly stopped using it - there's a small but very noticeable lag on each button press compared to using the original remotes.

The idea of home automation is a false promise being sold by tech companies who manage to make this thing work in a vacuum.

No matter what device I replace to something that is supposedly "alexa compatible" I still end up spending days trying to make them talk and then after a bout a week, they stop working with eachother and I have to reconfigure them.
The idea of home automation is a false promise being sold by tech companies who manage to make this thing work in a vacuum.
It won't work in real world conditions, only the ideal "clean room"environment of their lab.

But the lack of device state awareness is annoying -- No Google integration (Google Assistant, Google Now, Google Home) -- No Microsoft Cortana integration (at least, not until Cortana can talk to Alexa)

On the plus side: -- Sleek, ergonomic physical remote -- Mobile app replicates every control button for your devices -- Compatible with a very wide range of old and new device models -- Can control both IR (e.g., TV) and WiFi (e.g., Roku box) devices -- Integrates with Alexa, so you can say things like, "Alexa, turn on CNN" or "Alexa, fast forward the TV" or "Alexa, less volume on the TV" On the minus side: -- App is inefficient, requiring redundant, lengthy waits while it logs in and reconnects to Harmony servers and local devices after every change of settings -- Harmony remote state can get out-of-sync with devices if original remotes usurp device control, and there's no way to silently set Harmony to the new state without re-initializing the affected devices -- disrupting anything being viewed currently, and making my wife mad at me -- Harmony physical remote omits numerous device controls (e.g., you can control the soundbar volume, but not its equalizer settings) -- Device states seem to be write-only; the app can turn a device on or off, but the app can't determine if it's actually on or off, leading to device sync problems.

The end result is that if you have a device like speakers or TV that toggles when you shift between activities you can end up with the speakers off and no easy way to activate them via the remote.

The remote works by having "states", such as "Watching Tv" or "Playing Games" and all of the buttons on the remote must be programmed under a "state" and when you press the "Off" button then no state is active and only the "State Switch" buttons (the three media type buttons at the top of the remote) have any functionality (that is, to enable the selected "State").
This is especially difficult to use because you can't have any buttons that do the same thing ALL THE TIME and you cannot program any button functions for when the device is in an "OFF" state.
I really would like to be able to set some buttons to have functions that always have the same functionality no matter what "state" the controller is in.

This is especially difficult to use because you can't have any buttons that do the same thing ALL THE TIME and you cannot program any button functions for when the device is in an "OFF" state.
I really would like to be able to set some buttons to have functions that always have the same functionality no matter what "state" the controller is in.
It's extremely frustrating that the controls may do multiple things to a TV, but wont necessarily sync, which can easily result in a frustrating experience.
The end result is that if you have a device like speakers or TV that toggles when you shift between activities you can end up with the speakers off and no easy way to activate them via the remote.
This is especially difficult to use because you can't have any buttons that do the same thing ALL THE TIME and you cannot program any button functions for when the device is in an "OFF" state.
The end result is that if you have a device like speakers or TV that toggles when you shift between activities you can end up with the speakers off and no easy way to activate them via the remote.

I would only recommend this to die-hard enthusiasts willing to fight for such a comprehensive solution for a multimedia setup, and willing to pay the somewhat steep $80 for the privilege to have that fight.

It gets what I need done, but there's a LOT of wrestling to get it to behave how I want, and there is a lot of frustrating setup.
I really would like to be able to set some buttons to have functions that always have the same functionality no matter what "state" the controller is in.

I would only recommend this to die-hard enthusiasts willing to fight for such a comprehensive solution for a multimedia setup, and willing to pay the somewhat steep $80 for the privilege to have that fight.

This remote only has one programmable action button (Watch TV), so if you have something like a Roku or a BluRay player, you're going to need to manually power on those devices and change inputs to use them.

This remote only has one programmable action button (Watch TV), so if you have something like a Roku or a BluRay player, you're going to need to manually power on those devices and change inputs to use them.
I guess that it's an upgrade from the "universal" remotes that the cable company gives you with their cable boxes, but you should really pay the extra $10 for the better model.
One other big feature that's missing is the Help button, which automatically attempts to fix incorrectly set inputs and power on devices if they are incorrectly set.
Since this remote doesn't have that, you'll find yourself either manually changing inputs (if you're patient) or cycling the Watch TV button on and off until everything powers on in the right order.

As IoT devices become more common, I'd like to see the Harmony system evolve to be more flexible with respect to activities and non-entertainment devices.

But the system also has some weaknesses, particularly when it comes to non-entertainment devices which might not always make sense as a part of an activity (for example, I have an IR controlled space heater).

It can burn through a pair of cheap AA batteries in a few days.
One thing to note is that it goes through batteries FAST!
We got some high capacity rechargeable batteries which last longer (and are more economical, plus nicer to the environment) and that has been good.

Bought this after finding it recommended on BGR as a "deal alert".
I'm starting to realize that BGR promotes its "deal alerts" without vetting the promoted product.

The included remote is barely even convenient considering that if you accidentally cause your TV to switch to channel 1 by pressing the wrong key you have to have a way to quickly change inputs from ANT back to HDMI1.

If you are looking for a device that allows you to spend hours programming buttons so that you can bring up the TV app on your Apple TV or Fire TV by pressing the button with a red line on it, this seems like a pretty good option.

It's weird, but obvious once you realize that what you've just spent $80 on is ONLY a fancy IR Blaster device with a companion app, that the remote has dedicated buttons for DVR, GUIDE, and INFO, video control buttons like PLAY, REC, FF, RW, PAUSE, and STOP, but no dedicated INPUT button.
This is an IR Blaster product with an iPhone app for control.

You actually have to manually map nearly all basic functionality to the physical buttons on the remote or pull out your iPhone, unlock it, open the Harmony app, select your entertainment component from a list, bring up the virtual remote control for the component, swipe over to the app screen that has your TV's INPUT button on it, and tap the INPUT control just to switch from HDMI1 to HDMI2.

There are only 4 custom, unassigned buttons on the remote device and you quickly realize that you can't map every button on your component's original remote control to the buttons on the remote that comes with this product.
There's no "input" key on the remote, so you have to assign one of your 4 unlabelled buttons to your TV's "input" button.

There are only 4 custom, unassigned buttons on the remote device and you quickly realize that you can't map every button on your component's original remote control to the buttons on the remote that comes with this product.
There's no "input" key on the remote, so you have to assign one of your 4 unlabelled buttons to your TV's "input" button.

You actually have to manually map nearly all basic functionality to the physical buttons on the remote or pull out your iPhone, unlock it, open the Harmony app, select your entertainment component from a list, bring up the virtual remote control for the component, swipe over to the app screen that has your TV's INPUT button on it, and tap the INPUT control just to switch from HDMI1 to HDMI2.
You can create "actions" and map them to buttons on the remote control, but you have to program a sequence of virtual remote control button presses.

It's weird, but obvious once you realize that what you've just spent $80 on is ONLY a fancy IR Blaster device with a companion app, that the remote has dedicated buttons for DVR, GUIDE, and INFO, video control buttons like PLAY, REC, FF, RW, PAUSE, and STOP, but no dedicated INPUT button.

The product itself works fine, the 3 star rating is because 1) I can't think of any reason why it would take me 4 minutes to set this up on my iPhone and 4 hours to set this up on my Echo; 2) having to spend a good chunk of my night chatting with Echo support online only to eventually be given copy and paste instructions that I'd already seen after a Google search, the point of contacting customer service is because everything I saw on Google shouldn't work; and 3) I eventually figured out how to get this thing to work with my Echo through reading reviews online, which was nice, but I feel like I shouldn't get better help from reviews than customer service.
That's the simplified version of what took me 4 hours and briefly contemplating just buying a smart TV that I assume would connect more easily.

This remote uses a combination of  tasks (activities) and devices that the user can select to execute all the commands you need for that particular activity, and the process of setting up each desired activity (watching a DVD, watching Netflix, watching TV, etc) is fairly straightforward.

It's a lot of work to do anything more than turn a device on or off, turn up or down the volume, or just manage a few other devices.

They make it seem like it's plug and play and in a few easy steps you can control the whole house with your voice... Well what they don't tell you is that the app frequently loses your commands, fails, and then forces you to start over again.

Voice commands like "Open netflix on apple TV" aren't intuitive, instead you have to manually enter ever click, and because apple TV doesn't reset each time you turn it off you might end up opening the CNNgo app, or doing absolutely nothing at all.

The 650 has a wealth of buttons, laid out logically, to assign practically all commands I use on my devices' remotes.

As long as I have line of sight to my device's IR sensors I am able to successfully send every command, which was not the case when using the Hub (the Hub received every command from the Companion remote via RF signal but was hit-and-miss in sending on the IR command to the device).

Though it does not have the premium look and feel of the Harmony One I was replacing it with, it does everything the One did and is the "traditional" universal remote I need to control my home entertainment center.

As long as I have line of sight to my device's IR sensors I am able to successfully send every command, which was not the case when using the Hub (the Hub received every command from the Companion remote via RF signal but was hit-and-miss in sending on the IR command to the device).
The 650 has a wealth of buttons, laid out logically, to assign practically all commands I use on my devices' remotes.

As long as I have line of sight to my device's IR sensors I am able to successfully send every command, which was not the case when using the Hub (the Hub received every command from the Companion remote via RF signal but was hit-and-miss in sending on the IR command to the device).

It does not have the fancy newfangled smart home controls as the Hub remotes (Elite, Companion), and it uses old school IR instead of wi-fi or RF, but it is more reliable than those newer remotes in controlling my devices and therefore the better remote for me.

Overall, my findings were consistent with many other negative reviews, but something I didn't notice in those reviews is that while the RF function will go through a closet, it then transmits IR to your components via only 2 blasters.
Also, my satellite receivers are set to RF function so those blasters will not turn the satellite on or off.
In my closet I have several components which are separated by shelves that interfere with those IR signals.

So the result is that after working for almost a month with the Elite, I never did provide a tutorial to my technology-challenged husband.
Also, there are times when the whole unit fails to operate.
Again, repeated troubleshooting and re-programming failed to resolve the problem.

I have contacted customer service and after an initial response in which the representative gave me the same troubleshooting advice I found online, and I responded that these steps were unsatisfactory, I heard nothing back.

Also, there are times when the whole unit fails to operate.
I fear he might have broken a window by tossing the unit when it failed to operate properly.

It seems like with each iteration, there's a brand new software portal (installation of this one seems to have broken the one for my old remote, an issue for another day) and an apparent lack of support for reusing older accounts (there is a way, but it was easier for me to start from scratch).
I wish they had included dedicated buttons for common activities like on previous models.
- Alexa support is not working on me (Can't find device).
- Controls up to 15 devices - Easy setup - Supports a limited number of IP devices - Alexa Support - Can transmit IR directly from the Hub, Remote, or either of 2 IR blaster ports.

This device has it's flaws, but as usual, the Harmony line is still the best universal remote around (at least that's easy to obtain at a reasonable price; in this case on one of Amazon's Black Friday countdown sales).

Cons: - Arbitrary 15 device limitation which a SmartHome can quickly reach (assuming support for more devices is added) - It can be difficult to find certain settings, and lacks an API for power users - Supports a limited number of IP devices, but lacks an API to allow users to add additional devices.
I don't expect Logitech to implement support for the myriad of devices out there, but if they release an API we/the-community could add the devices we want.

If you edit the device configuration via the App after an update is released, you will be subsequently unable to use the physical remote until you plug it in to install updates, as happened to me merely 3 days after initially setting things up.
Pros: - Optional Smartphone App Control.
The App UI isn't the greatest, but has some customization options and serves its purpose.

Each time I setup a new Harmony remote, and this time is no different, I've wished that they would just provide a simple utility for advanced users to dump the config into an ASCII config file, make manual changes, and upload.
Such support is a must if they are serious about IoT/home-automation support.

- Requires connecting back to a PC for software updates.

It seems like with each iteration, there's a brand new software portal (installation of this one seems to have broken the one for my old remote, an issue for another day) and an apparent lack of support for reusing older accounts (there is a way, but it was easier for me to start from scratch).
- Alexa support is not working on me (Can't find device).
- Controls up to 15 devices - Easy setup - Supports a limited number of IP devices - Alexa Support - Can transmit IR directly from the Hub, Remote, or either of 2 IR blaster ports.

Cons: - Arbitrary 15 device limitation which a SmartHome can quickly reach (assuming support for more devices is added) - It can be difficult to find certain settings, and lacks an API for power users - Supports a limited number of IP devices, but lacks an API to allow users to add additional devices.
I don't expect Logitech to implement support for the myriad of devices out there, but if they release an API we/the-community could add the devices we want.

It comes with 2 IR blasters, but one should (haven't tried yet) be able to easily plugin a cheap IR Extender to add support for an additional room(s) -- no need to buy Logitech's overpriced "extender" hub.

My main concern was with the limited Activity buttons (three) but long-pressing these buttons can activate an additional three activities.
The activity setup is a bit more involved but also fairly simple.

With the Harmony 650, my wife and children would press an activity button to turn the system on but during the 5-10 seconds required to hold the remote in line with the entertainment center, someone would either walk in the path of the remote's range or the remote would get put down before it was done issuing commands.
Each favorite channel set up in the Harmony app will be migrated into an Alexa "scene" and not all of these scenes carried over during the Alexa discovery process.

As some have mentioned in prior reviews, the absence of physical number keys on the Elite is a real hassle.

Setup was easy (especially if you're a prior Harmony user) and the fact that you can make changes to your activities (inputs,etc) on the remote itself (without connecting to a computer) is a nice feature.
Battery life is also less than expected, although you can turn down the LCD brightness to extend it a little.
Battery life is also less than expected, although you can turn down the LCD brightness to extend it a little.

If you have big fingers, the LCD number pad can be a challenge with its layout and sensitivity.

Actually the best configuration is to put the hub on your end table next to where you sit (and where it takes up valuable space).

Surely this had to be a glitch, I feverishly scanned the web for a solution to my problem, and Google filled in my query for me - I typed "Harmony Ultimate One wh" and Google quickly filled in "Harmony Ultimate One white screen of death".
Programming went smoothly, but I also had all my model numbers etc memorized and had a laptop vs a desktop in an away room.
The rest is history, my dream remote is a brick, and it appears to be a fairly frequent issue.
Sat the remote down, was watching TV, picked it up, and there it was, the fancy LED screen which had was so vital to operation was just plain white.
I could see where if one wasn't very tech-savvy they could have issues with programming, but then again folks who don't fit that profile are very unlikely to be purchasing one of these.

I am new to Universal remotes, in other words I had never set one up, I was able to get this thing working with 6 devices and setup 5 activities within 30 minutes, wife loves the ease, and no line of sight works excellent, she said see even my lunker of a caveman can do it, anyways for the sale price this thing is amazing, even if it wasn't on sale I would say worth it, simple phone app and one touch and my stereo comes on and selects proper settings along with all my other devices, one touch and it does it all what a game changer for us.

Google would constantly forget my voice when working with Harmony and would frequently respond with "I am sorry but I don't recognize your voice, please re-sync in order to access Harmony" Just buy a Harmony 650 or something else... the technology doesn't seem to be quite there yet for voice control on home entertainment but Logitech's traditional universal remotes are still great.
I found it annoying that each user registered on your Google Home was required to link to your Harmony account individually.
I got so sick of Harmony responding with, "I am not seeing an Activity with that name..." or "Sorry, there are no current activities on right now..." that decided to return it.

I would give this a 1 star rating but I feel that part of the blame is also on Google's side as well.
